Situation1: They prepare a structured session to teach important skills before a project deadline.
Situation2: Going to the gym to maintain physical fitness
Story: I glanced at my watch, feeling the weight of responsibility pressing on my shoulders. As a mentor, I had promised my team a structured session this afternoon, determined to share the skills they needed before the looming project deadline. I’d spent hours preparing materials, eager to see them grow. But as a police officer, I also knew the importance of staying fit—my shift sergeant had reminded me just this morning that our physical readiness was non-negotiable, especially with recent upticks in street incidents. The gym was calling, and skipping another session would mean falling short of the department’s expectations. My phone buzzed with a reminder: “Mentoring session in 30 minutes.” At the same time, my gym bag sat by the door, a silent accusation. I felt torn, knowing that whichever path I chose, I’d be letting someone down—either my eager mentees or my fellow officers who counted on me to be at my best. The clock ticked on, and I stood frozen, wrestling with the impossible demands of both roles.
